editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Delivered in XIV. Sermons,

div.head: TO THE VERTVOVS AND NOBLE GENTLEMEN, Mr. EDWARD MOVNTAGVE, Mr. WILLIAM MOVNTAGVE, Mr. CHRISTOPHER MOVNTAGVE, and to the vertuous and noble Gentlewoman, Mrs. MANNERS, Children of the right honourable EDWARD Lord MOVNTAGVE of Boughton, in the County of NORTHHAMPTON. Grace and peace.
div.p:
I Formerly con≈øidering (worthy and honourable) what a bountifull Patrone your honourable father hath beene (and ≈øtill is) to me; not onely in giving me freely a pre≈øentation to the place where I now am, when I had little or no relation to his Honour; nor yet de≈øiring any ≈øuch favour from his Lord≈øhip: But al≈øo by a continuall ≈øupply of his many bounties and favours to me, and mine; con≈øulted with my ≈øelfe to te≈øtifie my gratitude to him, as Eli≈øha with his ≈øervant to the bountifull Shunamite, 2 King. 4. 13. And finding my ≈øelfe as unable to plea≈øure him by ≈øpeaking, &c. As that is needle≈ø≈øe, he dwelling among his owne
people, being knowne and honoured, in Court and Countrey. Yet con≈øidering that ≈øomething was to be done for him, as Eli≈øha for her, Ver. 14. I re≈øolved to ≈øhew my thankfulne≈ø≈øe to him (as Eli≈øha to the Shunamite in a child) in you his children, by fore-warning you of, and fore-arming you against the Sirenian and ≈øinfull inchauntments of Sathans instruments, to draw awry your young and flexible yeares into wayes uneven, and unequall. For this cau≈øe I gave you in writing, an Epi≈øtle per≈øwading you to imitate your vertuous Parents in their many pious and prai≈øe-worthy practices: to which I adjoyned this Di≈øcour≈øe of Spirituall Goodfellow≈øhip; not then intending any further publication: Yet now I have pre≈øumed to publi≈øh the ≈øame (being per≈øwaded and incouraged thereunto by many Divines, e≈øpecially two Batchelours in Divinitie; (M. Robert Boulton, and M. Nicolas E≈øtwicke) Lecturers at Kettering, who heard the Sermons preached, and peru≈øed my Booke. They being knowne in the Vniver≈øities where they have beene Students and Fellowes of Colledges; in the Countrey where they live, and el≈øewhere; to be grave, reverend. godly, and judicious Divines) under your patronage, and protection. Per≈øwading my ≈øelfe, that I adventuring to divulge this little Treati≈øe in an age ≈øo
learned and judicious, ≈øhalbe que≈øtioned like the Wi≈øe mans poore man, What fellow is this, &c? And Chri≈øt Ie≈øus my Lord and Ma≈øter is not this, &c. that di≈øgracefull di≈øe≈øteeme of good things by mean men, of which Ie≈øus the ≈øon of Sirach ≈øpeaketh, Eccle≈øia≈øticus 13. 23. ≈øaying, When a rich man ≈øpeaketh, every man holdeth his tongue, and looke what he ≈øaith, they extoll it to the clouds; but if the poore man ≈øpeake, they ≈øay what fellow is this? And Ie≈øus the Sonne of God found verified in him≈øelfe, of whom they ≈øaid, Is not this the Carpenter, the ≈øonne of Mary?‚Äîwhence hath he ≈øuch wi≈ødome, &c? Marke 6. 3. Being more now then heretofore. As for mine Epi≈øtle which I gave you to be as a gla≈ø≈øe whereby you may more ea≈øily take notice of, and as a booke of records to further your remembrances of the many worthy examples of your renowned Parents, although I have kept it (though unwillingly, it being fitted for this Tractate, opening ≈øomethings in the ≈øame, and per≈øwading by practice and examples, as this by Doctrine and Precept: it having had the approbation of my betters by farre to accompany the ≈øame (being accommodated thereunto) a≈øwell in publique as in private) from publique view. Yet my hope and earne≈øt de≈øire is, that you (right noble
and vertuous) will profitably peru≈øe both that and this to practice both, a≈ø≈øuring you, that by walking in tho≈øe wayes trac'd out by your religious Parents, and de≈øcrib'd in this Di≈øcour≈øe, you ≈øhalbe ≈øure to plea≈øe God, glad the good, put to ≈øilence the contrary minded, declare your reverent e≈øteeme of your godly Parents, in not degenerating from their Chri≈øtian cour≈øes, and manife≈øt your ≈øelves to be true and living members of this incomparable goodfellow≈øhip with all true beleevers, the Father, and his Sonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. Thus de≈øiring you, and all good Chri≈øtian Readers to give God the glory, and me your prayers. I leave them, and you, to read for your direction this following Di≈øcour≈øe in few houres, which I have painfully collected for the good of Gods Church, not without great labour, and much time; be≈øeeching the Lord Iehovah, ble≈ø≈øed for ever, to grace my honourable Lord, his vertuous Lady, and all his noble Children with all ≈øpirituall ble≈øsings, untill he bring them to glory, the perfection of grace.

closer.signed: Servant to you all for the ≈øalvation of your ≈øoules, IOSEPH BENTHAM.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
IT is the glory of true vertue to appeare as ≈øhe is, and to be ≈øeene in her owne proper colours: wherein ≈øhe hath a glorious triumph over vice, which, though audacious and impudent, yet is ≈øhe a≈øhamed of her owne face, and ≈øeekes to cover it with the vaile of vertue. In≈øtance Idolatry, which puts on the maske of Piety, Super≈øtition of Religion, Hypocri≈øie of Sincerity, Covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe of Thriftine≈ø≈øe, Prodigality of Liberality, Lewd fellow≈øhip of Good-fellow≈øhip. Hereupon the lewde≈øt companions that can be, ≈øuch as feare nor God nor man, ≈øuch as take libertie to all loo≈øene≈ø≈øe and licentiou≈øne≈ø≈øe, committing all manner of ≈øinne with greedine≈ø≈øe, Carders, Dicers, Swearers, Swaggerers, Gluttons, Drunkards, and others like them, very bea≈øts in humane ≈øhapes, Swine, Dogs, Toads, A≈øpes, yea Devils incarnate, take upon them the name of Good-fellowes, and entitle their abominable and execrable communion Good-fellow≈øhip. Herein they have prevailed as farre as Papi≈øts in their undue and uniu≈øt u≈øurpation of the title Catholicke: entituling their Apo≈øtaticall and Antichri≈øtian Church the Catholick Church: and to make their blindne≈ø≈øe (or rather madne≈ø≈øe) the more manife≈øt to the whole world, they ioyne the≈øe two contradictory titles together, Romi≈øh-Catholick ‚Ä¢ . Yet herein they have ≈øo farre prevailed, as not onely them≈øelves a≈ø≈øume, but others al≈øo give them that title Catholicke. But how? Surely in way of ≈øcorne and deri≈øion: as the Holy Gho≈øt giveth the ≈øtile of Gods to Idols. As Papi≈øts, ≈øo other lewd companions have ≈øo farre prevailed by u≈øurping to them≈øelves this ≈øtile Good-fellowes, and to their ≈øociety this title Good fellow≈øhip, as others al≈øo that are not of that fraternity give them and their diveli≈øh ≈øociety this ≈øtile and title. Wherefore to pull away the≈øe ≈øtollen feathers from that blacke crow, that foule crew, this Treati≈øe is penned: wherein is declared, who are the onely true Good-fellowes, and what is the only true Good-fellow≈øhip, namely the Saints and their Societie. In handling which point thou ha≈øt (good Reader) ≈øet before thee as the particulars whereof that Good-fellow≈øhip con≈øi≈øteth, ≈øo the ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe and amiablene≈ø≈øe, the dignity, and excellency thereof, and many other allurements to draw thee thereto; together with directions how to obtaine a freedome in that fellow≈øhip, and how to carie thy ≈øelfe worthy thereof, an≈øwerable thereto. Be more diligent inviewing and well ob≈øerving the matter of this Treati≈øe, then in enquiring after the Author thereof Expede
Herculem. By this ≈ømall parcell of his paines, thou mai≈øt iudge what the man is. Yea by a ≈øtudious reading of this Booke thou mai≈øt know thy ≈øelfe, and under≈øtand of what company thou art. Thou mai≈øt hereby iudge of companies, and know which is the be≈øt. In this Treati≈øe thou ≈øhalt finde that the true Good-fellowes here de≈øcribed have a ≈øweet communion one with another, yea and with the Father, and his Sonne. What high prerogatives and excellent priviledges the≈øe be, what cordials are thence mini≈øtred to poore di≈øtre≈ø≈øed ≈øoules, what thereupon to be avoided, what to be endeavoured after, are di≈øtinctly and ≈øuccinctly ≈øet out in this Di≈øcour≈øe. Such apt and iu≈øt con≈øequences are diducted from the principall Points, as mo≈øt, if not all the heads of our Chri≈øtian Religion are explaned. Brevity and Per≈øpicuity are here ioyned together. Read, and marke, and thou ≈øhalt find ≈øuch varietie of matter as will mini≈øter delight with profit. Thus much I thought good to give thee notice of, not ≈øimply to commend the worke, but rather to incite thee to ≈øeeke after the trea≈øure which is hid therein, that ≈øo thou mai≈øt ≈øhew thy ≈øelfe like the wi≈øe Merchant, who having heard of a Pearle of great price, and of a rich trea≈øure, could not be quiet till he had got them, as the Lord noteth among his Parables. Farewell in the Lord.

closer.signed: Thine in the Lord, G. M.

Had you knowne how learnedly, and orthodoxallyProbemus extructionem potius legis & prophetar ‚Ä¢ o inveniri in Christo, quam de≈øtructionem. Lib. 1. Contra Marcionem. pag. 260. So abounding with ≈øuch multiplicity of various impieties, then which no ≈øervice more tedious and trouble≈øome, wherein a man ≈øerves, not two, but a multitude of Ma≈øters, ≈øerving ≈øinne in the lu≈øts thereof, Rom. 6. 12. 3. So cruell, then which none more tyrannicall, and bloudy; paying its be≈øt ob≈øervants with as bad wages as may be; eternall death, Rom. 6. 23. Iam. 1. 15. The≈øe are ≈øervices, but not like ours, although worldlings now as in Iobs time, ≈øay or thinke, What is the Almighty, that we ≈øhould ≈øerve him; and in Malachy 3. 17. it is in vaine to ≈øerve God: Yet we know this ≈øervice to be of all other.

1. Mo≈øt honourable: For, 1. Our Ma≈øter is not ≈øome Kings greate≈øt favourite, nor yet ≈øome potent Prince, nor yet a terrene Monarch, ≈øwaying the Soveraigne Scepter for his
time of the whole world; But a Lord of Lords, and King of Kings, who≈øe is the kingdome, the power, and glory; then which no Ma≈øter more honourable. 2. Our fellow-≈øervants are all the holy ones of God, as Abraham; and tho≈øe pious Patriarches, ≈øuch as Mo≈øes and Eliah, and tho≈øe Divine Prophets: ≈øuch as David, and tho≈øe other godly Governours: the heavenly company of glorious Angels, Rev. 19. 10. Yea, our ble≈ø≈øed Saviour, our fellow-≈øervant, Phil. 2. 7. Then which no fellow-≈øervants more honourable.

2. Mo≈øt gainefull: the≈øe ≈øervants gaine Christ, Phil 3. 8. Pardon of ≈øinnes, Gods favour, his ble≈ø≈øed Spirit; yea, temporall favours, if commodious for them, ≈øhall moreover and above be added to them, Mat. 6. 33. If they have not riches, it is becau≈øe they are not good for them. If they want health,Temporalia non ≈øunt bona, ni≈øi in quantum ordinantur in coelestia. it is becau≈øe it is not good for them. If their life is cut ≈øhort, they are taken away from the evill to come. Yea moreover, as this ≈øervice gaines all things, 1 Cor. 3. 21. &c. And as a good friend loves at all times, Prov. 17. 7. So this ≈øervice brings in gaines at all ≈øea≈øons, in ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, and health, pro≈øperity, and adver≈øity, Rom. 8. 28. Yea, in life, and death, Phil. 1. 22. Another man dies, his gaines die with him, P≈øal. 49. 17. His trea≈øure was laid up on earth, therefore leaving this world he parts with his trea≈øure: the ≈øervant of God dies, his gaines follow him, Rev. 14. 13. His trea≈øure was laid up in heaven, departing hence therefore he followes his trea≈øure, goes to his gaine: Perhaps he forgoes a materiall building, and layes downe an earthly tabernacle; but he finds a building given of God, not made with hands, eternall in the heavens, 2 Cor. 5. 1. He leaves behind him ≈øome worldly ≈øub≈øtance; but gets in heaven a better and enduring ≈øub≈øtance, Heb. 10. 34. Peradventure he may part with ≈øome corruptible inheritance, to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of an inheritance incorruptible, re≈øerved in heaven, 1 Pet. 1. 4. Where he hath ≈øo much, that he is ever ≈øatisfied; and ≈øo much to come, that he is never glutted: where there is infinite abundance of all things, and yet infinite more to come.

3. Mo≈øt delightfull: David had an honourable ≈øervice,
a≈øcending from keeping ≈øheepe to be ≈øonne in law to a King. Iacob a gainefull, growing from alone man, and a ≈øtaffe into a populous family, and certaine droves; but neither had much delight in his ≈øervice. But as there is honour and profit in this ≈øervice, ≈øo there is plenitude of delight, and con≈øolation. For, 1. Our Master is no churli≈øh Nabal, to whom a man could not ≈øpeake, 1 Sam. 25. 17. No unkind Laban, but a God mo≈øt mercifull and pitifull; gracious and favourable; patient and long ≈øuffering. He termes his ≈øervants friends, I≈øa. 41. 8. Yea, ≈øonnes, Exod. 4. 23. He layes upon us no burden≈øome yoke, but ≈øuch which is ea≈øie and light, Math. 11. 28. Not grievous, 1 Ioh. 5. 3. But the rejoycing of our hearts, P≈øal. 119. 111. I need not go from my Point in hand to fetch this threefold cord which is not ea≈øily broken. Tho≈øe who truly ≈øerve the Lord, have fellow≈øhip with the Father, then which what more honourable, gainfull, or delightfull? Good ≈øervants 1. obey their Ma≈øters precepts. 2. Spend the chiefe of their time in their Ma≈øters bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. 3. Delight to plea≈øe them. 4. Have no intimate ≈øociety with their Ma≈øters profe≈ø≈øed enemies. 5. Cannot endure to ≈øee or heare them abu≈øed. 6. And feare to offend them. Be we ≈øuch good ≈øervants. 1. Obeying the will and Word of God. 2. Spending the day of our time in his ≈øervice, walking Enoch-like with God, Gen. 5. 24. 3. Ioy in plea≈øing our ≈øo good and gracious Ma≈øter. 4. Avoiding intimate familiarity with his enemies. 5. Not enduring to heare or ≈øee him di≈øhonoured. 6. And fearing to offend him. Thus let us ≈øerve him; this ≈øerving being a duty we owe, if we have, or meanes to obtaine if we want fellow≈øhip with the Father.

div.head: OF THE SOCIETIE OF THE SAINTS, the fourth Booke.
div.p: NOW I come to the fourth and la≈øt part of the true goodfellow≈øhip, con≈øi≈øting betwixt the Head and members: And with his Sonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. This part of the true goodfellow≈øhip is not the lea≈øt, although the la≈øt. For by fellow≈øhip with Chri≈øt, we have fellow≈øhip with the Saints, and without Chri≈øt Ie≈øus there is no fellow≈øhip for man with God. I will now forbeare to ≈øpeake of the≈øe three titles, his Sonne, Ie≈øus, Chri≈øt: It only ≈øufficeth for the pre≈øent to tell you that Chri≈øt is Gods Sonne. 1. By Nature. According to his Divine nature he and he onely is the Sonne of God, being begotten of the ≈øame ≈øub≈øtance of the Father by an everla≈øting generation, Math. 17. 5. 2. By Grace of per≈øonall union, the manhood of Chri≈øt being un≈øeparably united to the per≈øon of the Sonne of God, Luke 1. 35. The Saints are Gods Sonnes by Adoption, Rom. 8. 17. Yea, all profe≈ø≈øours without practice are Gods Sonnes, although by profe≈ø≈øion onely, Gen. 6. 1. The creatures may be termed Gods Sonnes commonly. Saints are Gods Sonnes ≈øpecially. But Chri≈øt is Gods Sonne ≈øingularly.

div.head: CHAP. I. The Saints have fellow≈øhip with Chri≈øt.
div.p: Doct. 4 ALL true believers, Saints, or faithfull Chri≈øtians have ≈øocietie, fellow≈øhip or communion with Ie≈øus Chri≈øt the Sonne of God.

[With his Son Ie≈øus Chri≈øt] Ioh. 15. 1, 2, 3, 4. I am the true vine, ye are the branches, 17. 23. 26. 21. I in them, &c. Eph. 3. 17. That Chri≈øt may dwell in your hearts by faith. Gal. 2. 20. I live, yet not I, but Chri≈øt lives in me.
Rea≈øon 1 All tho≈øe who are Chri≈øt his fellowes have fellow≈øhip with Ie≈øus Chri≈øt the Sonne of God.

But all true believers, Saints, or faithfull Chri≈øtians are Chri≈øt his fellowes (for Chri≈øt hath taken them into fellow≈øhip of him≈øelfe, and his merits, P≈øal. 45. 7.) Therefore all true believers, Saints, &c. Have fellow≈øhip with Ie≈øus Chri≈øt the Sonne of God.
That they are Chri≈øt his fellowes, I prove thus.

But all true believers, Saints, or faithfull Chri≈øtians are,

2. Tho≈øe who are linkt and conglutinated in the firme≈øt connexion of the Matrimoniall knot and conjugall yoke, have fellow≈øhip each with other.

But Chri≈øt Ie≈øus and all true believers, Saints, or faithfull Chri≈øtians are linkt and conglutinated in the firme≈øt connexion of the Matrimoniall knot, and conjugall yoke: therefore have fellow≈øhip each with other.
The fir≈øt Propo≈øition is cleare: I prove the ≈øecond or minor thus.
Tho≈øe who are bride, and bridegroome; husband and wife, are linkt and conglutinated in the firme≈øt connexion of the Matrimoniall knot, and Conjugall yoke.
But Chri≈øt Ie≈øus is the Bridegroome or Husband; all true belieuers, Saints, &c. are the bride. Therefore Chri≈øt and Chri≈øtians are linkt and conglutinated, &c.

1. He wooeth, be≈øeeching us by his Mini≈øters, 2 Cor. 5. 20.
2. He contracts him≈øelfe unto the Church by a firme and free promi≈øe of mariage with his Church with the con≈øent of his Father.

Husbands ought entirely to love their wives, Col. 3. 19. Eph. 5. 22. Love them they ought; for they are good things, Prov. 18. 22. For they are their companions, Mal. 2. 14. And their owne fle≈øh, Eph. 5. 28. Chri≈øt Ie≈øus loved his Church with ≈øuch entire and ardent love, that he gave him≈øelfe
for his Church. But becau≈øe I will not ≈øtay upon conjugall duties; in briefe I ≈øay; that no husband ever; nay if the excellency of all the mo≈øt melting affectionatene≈ø≈øe, and other chiefe vertues could be drawne out of all mankind that have beene, are, or ≈øhalbe, and infu≈øed into ≈øome Angelicall body; yet could not this imagined excellent husband love with ≈øuch a ≈øincere, and perpetuall love, cleave ≈øo clo≈øely and compactedly unto; give ≈øuch honor, or due benevolence unto, con≈øolate with ≈øuch ravi≈øhing comforts, graunt more willingly the hone≈øt and rea≈øonable reque≈øts, governe, guide, and direct more prudently a wife lovely beyond imagination, as Christ Ie≈øus doth the Church, or true believers, Saints, or faithfull Chri≈øtians his Spou≈øe.

That all true believers are the Spou≈øe of Chri≈øt is per≈øpicuou≈øly tran≈øparent, Rev. 19. 7, 8. 21. 9. 22. 27. Iohn 3. 29. And in this that they owe the ≈øelfe≈øame duties to Chri≈øt Ie≈øus which wives do owe to their husbands. ≈øc. Subjection, reverence, obedience, &c.

But all true believers, Saints, or faithfull Chri≈øtians are ingrafted or inoculated into Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. Therefore all true believers, &c. have fellow≈øhip with Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, the &c.
The latter Propo≈øition I prove out of Ioh. 15. 1, 2.
1. There is a husbandman, who is the Father, ju≈øtly called the husbandman: for,

1. He hath a rightfull intere≈øt unto, and an ab≈øolute Soveraigne authority over his ≈øpirituall vine, vineyard, and branches; his is the right, not by Law, but by nature; not from any ≈øuperiour, but from him≈øelfe, and he may do with it what he will.
2. In regard of affection, the affection that he beares to this vine, vineyard, and branches is tran≈øcendent; he loves them tenderly, and delights in them wonderfully.
3. In regard of his actions: for,
1. He doth plant, i. e. joyne the elect taken out of the rotten ≈øtocke of old Adam unto Chri≈øt and his Church by the ≈øpirit. P≈øal. 92. 13. Rom. 6. 5.
2. He doth water with the true doctrine of his Word, the holy ≈øpirit, and ≈øaving graces, Ezek 36. 15.
3. He doth expect as earne≈øtly fruit from his vineyard, as the husbandman doth from his, I≈øa. 5. 2.

4. He doth prune and purge out blindne≈ø≈øe by the word of Knowledge, errour by the Word of Confutation, de≈øperation, by the word of Con≈øolation, &c. and he pre≈øerves, &c. and on the contrary he rejects the fruitle≈ø≈øe branches, that ≈øo they may wither, and be burned, Iohn 15. 2. 4. 6.

2. There is al≈øo a Vine, and there are branches abiding in that vine, Iohn 15. 4. Chri≈øt is a vine giving life of grace to all his members, as a vine gives juyce and life to all its branches; he mini≈øtreth to Chri≈øtians the ≈øappe of his grace, and ≈øpirit, whereby they live, grow, and bring forth good workes; even as a vine doth mini≈øter to the branches moy≈øture, ≈øappe, and juyce, whereby they live, flouri≈øh, and beare fruit. In this vine the roote is Chri≈øt, his God-head the ≈øtemme, his Manhood, the ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ppe, his graces, the branches, true beleevers, and the grapes good workes. Neither is this contradicted, where the Church is called a vine, P≈øal. 80. 9. 14. I≈øa. 5. 1. 2. 3. A vine it is who≈øe ≈øen≈øe is Gods protection, who≈øe preachers are its watchmen, their doctrines and exhortations as a winepre≈ø≈øe to wring out good duties as ≈øweet iuyce; and who≈øe grapes are good workes as plea≈øant fruite. Nor where Chri≈øt is called a branch as he oftentimes is, Ier. 33. 15. Zach. 3. 8. 6. 12. for when Chri≈øt is a branch, his Church is the vine, him≈øelfe the Head or chiefe branch, his Saints inferiour twigs, his graces ≈øappe, blo≈ø≈øome, bud, and grapes. When the Church is a vine, Chri≈øt wholy is the roote, and ≈øtock; true beleevers the branches, who≈øe obedience is the fruits, or plea≈øant grapes; which way ≈øoever they are ingrafted into Chri≈øt. Therefore have fellow≈øhip with Ie≈øus Chri≈øt the Sonne of God.

Tho≈øe who being knit together by the ≈øpirit, are laid as living ≈øtones upon Chri≈øt the foundation, or head corner ≈øtone to be an habitation of God, have fellow≈øhip with Ie≈øus Chri≈øt the Sonne of God; becau≈øe they are ≈øtones of that building whereof he is the foundation.
But all true beleevers are built together, or laid upon Chri≈øt Ie≈øus the foundation, &c. Ephe≈ø. 2. 20, 21, 22. 1. Pet. 2. 5. 6, 7. Therefore Chri≈øt Ie≈øus is:

1. That ≈øtone in Daniel 2. 43. cut out of the mountaines without hands; being not ≈øet up by man, but ≈øent by God. 2. A ≈øtone of offence, 1. Pet. 2. 8. to unbeleevers, and misbeleevers, they peri≈øhing by refu≈øing to be laid upon this ≈øtone. 3. A pretious ≈øtone, 1. Pet. 2. 6. hee being of exceeding great value, more worth then millions of worlds. 4. A living ≈øtone, 1. Pet. 2. 4. pre≈øerving the faithfull in the life of grace to the life of glory. 5. A ≈øtone with ≈øeaven eyes, Zach. 4. 10. in regard Gods providence watcheth graciou≈øly over all ≈øuch who are built upon this ≈øtone. 6. Yea the foundation of his Church, and cho≈øen, 1. Cor. 3. 10, 11. Other foundation can no man lay, then that is layd, which is Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, Ephe≈ø. 2. 20. Ie≈øus Chri≈øt him≈øelfe being the chiefe corner ≈øtone, 1. Pet. 2. 6.

True it is, that the decree of Gods election grounded upon his everla≈øting love is a foundation, 2. Tim. 2. 19. becau≈øe the godly are ≈øtayed upon this, as a hou≈øe upon the foundation. 2. Chri≈øtian doctrine is a foundation al≈øo, Heb. 6. 1. It being a meanes to build men upon Chri≈øt the foundation. 3. Chri≈øtian princes, and Magi≈øtrates are thus ≈øtiled, P≈øal. 82. 5. becau≈øe the quiet of the Church doth re≈øt upon them, as a hou≈øe on the foundation. 4. The Apo≈øtles, and Prophets, Ephe≈ø. 2. 20. Not onely Peter (tho≈øe who make Peter the foundation whereon the Church is built. 1. Fal≈øifye the Text, which is, not ∆≤pon thee Peter, but ∆≤pon this Rocke. 2. Deale reprochfully with Chri≈øt, lifting Peter into the roome of his Ma≈øter. 3. Injuriou≈øly with the Church, building it upon ≈øo weake a rocke which ≈øo often failed) but the Apo≈øtles and Prophets all of them as well as he are foundations (viz. ≈øecond, and
≈øubordinate) becau≈øe by their doctrien they lay the elect upon Chri≈øt the true foundation: which is the true foundation of the Church in regard of his per≈øon, and office. 1. Hee being the corner ≈øtone, or firme foundation whereon his Church is built. 2. He ≈øupporting, and bearing it Vp, as a foundation, again≈øt the gates of hell, that they cannot prevaile again≈øt it.
As Chri≈øt is the foundation, ≈øo Gods faithfull Mini≈øters are the builders, 1. Cor. 3. 10. laying the Elect upon Chri≈øt, as builders doe one ≈øtone upon another, and all upon the foundation.

And the Saints are the ≈øtones. 1. Called lively, 1. Pet. 2. 5. becau≈øe they are quickened with the life of God by the doctrine of the go≈øpell. 2. Stones made up into a ≈øpirituall hou≈øe, Ephe≈ø. 2. 20, 21, 22. becau≈øe they are founded on Chri≈øt the head ≈øtone. They are therefore called Gods building, 1. The head is the ≈øeate of rea≈øon, memory, imagination, and ≈øen≈øes; It gives life and motion to the members: From the head, the body by joynts and bands hath nouri≈øhment mini≈øtred, is knit together, and increa≈øeth, Col. 2. 19. Therefore head, and members have ≈øociety one with another.

All true beleevers are members, &c. Chri≈øt the head, &c. Ephe≈ø. 4. 12. edifying the body of Christ. 15. head even Chri≈øt, 5. 13. Christ is the head of the Church, 30. for we are members of his body, of his fle≈øh, and of his bones, 1. 22. gave him≈øelfe to bee head over all things to the Church, ver. 23. which is his body.

div.head: CHAP. II. ∆≤≈øe 1. Reprehending tho≈øe who harme the Saints.
div.p:
HOw dare you, O you ≈øonnes of Belial, harme, or hurt,
∆≤≈øe 1. Of Reprehen≈øion. di≈øgracefully deride, or per≈øecute with hand, heart, or tongue the≈øe who have fellow≈øhip with Chri≈øt? Who≈øe Word ≈øo potent, that by it he created the univer≈øall world: by it he ca≈øt out Devils; ≈øtilled the raging waves of the impetuous ≈øea, healed incurable di≈øea≈øes, vanqui≈øhed Sathan, and con≈øumeth Antichri≈øt, 2 The≈ø. 2. 8. The ≈øubjects of this King. 7. The brethren and ≈øi≈øters of this Brother. 8. The ≈øheepe of this Shepheard. 9. The Bride of this husband. 10. The members of this head?

and drie. 3. Beare fruit which is ≈øweet in it ≈øelfe, plea≈øant to the u≈øer, and profitable to the owner. 4. 3. The≈øe are the ≈øpou≈øe of Chri≈øt; therefore they ought to love, reverence, and feare him, heare his voice, and receive his in≈øtructions, obey his commandements, and be clad with his mariage garments, ≈øc. the gifts and graces of his Spirit.

div.head: CHAP. XII. The Conclu≈øion, ≈øhewing the drift of all.
div.p: BY that which I have ≈øpoken at ≈øundry times from this place concerning this ≈øubject of true goodfellow≈øhip, ≈øhewing from ≈øacred Writ who and what goodfellowes are; wiping away many foule and filthy a≈øper≈øions wherewith the world doth fal≈øely blemi≈øh them; and declaring their duties and dignity.

Fir≈øt, I hope you ≈øee the errour and inju≈øtice of this erroneous world, depriving Gods Saints of this their rightfull denomination; and conferring it upon the mo≈øt ≈øtigmaticall ≈øonnes of Belial. Is he a goodfellow truly, and onely who hath fellow≈øhip with the Saints, the Lord of heaven and earth, and his Sonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt; And are they which ≈øtrive to imitate the Saints, endeavour to plea≈øe God, and labour to have intere≈øt in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, ba≈øe companions, in≈øociable per≈øons, and unworthy the name of goodfellowes, becau≈øe they preferre this excellent communion before the bea≈øtly and Diabolicall ≈øociety with the fruitle≈ø≈øe workes, and unhappy workers if darkne≈ø≈øe? And ≈øhall ≈øuch which make open profe≈ø≈øion of the Devills ≈øervice, are at open defiance with all manner of goodne≈ø≈øe, be ≈øtiled and e≈øteemed goodfellowes, becau≈øe with ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe foreheads, and flinty hearts they wallow in all manner of wickedne≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe they ≈øweare and ≈øwagger, roare, and revell, ≈øcorne and ≈øcoffe at goodne≈ø≈øe, and good men, con≈øume wa≈øtfully their patrimonies and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions in pipes and pots, in Tavernes and Taphou≈øes, in drunkenne≈ø≈øe, and other damnable cour≈øes? Yet this is the u≈øuall and common dealing of the mo≈øt, although impious and ungodly; for what right have Sathans imps and agents to this holy title of goodfellow?

Heare our Church ≈øpeake, which ≈øaith: If we lacke Ie≈øus Chri≈øt: that is to ≈øay, the Saviour of our ≈øoules and bodies, we ≈øhall not finde him in the market place, or in the Guilde Hall,
much le≈ø≈øe in the Ale-hou≈øe or Taverne amongst goodfellowes, as they call them, &c. Hom. of right u≈øe of the Church, Fol. 6.

Let drunken bea≈øts and pot-companions; Let infatuated prodigals, and riotous ≈øpend-thrifts; Let ≈øwa≈øhing ≈øwaggerers, who ≈øport them≈øelves at the godly ≈øimplicity of hone≈øt men, and all other of the ≈øame kind a≈ø≈øume to them≈øelves, and give to their companions their owne proper titles: ≈øc. fooles, bea≈øts, ≈øonnes of Belial, &c. And not incroach upon this title which is properly due to none but ≈øuch who have fellow≈øhip with the Saints, the Father, and his Sonne Ie≈øus Christ.

Secondly, I hope that you under≈øtand ≈øufficiently by the foregoing di≈øcour≈øes the admirable and un≈øpeakable priviledges of all goodfellowes, or true believers: being combined by the mo≈øt a≈øtrictive ties in fellow≈øhip with the Lord of glory, his ble≈ø≈øed Sonne, and gracious Saints, and Servants. As al≈øo the wretched and mi≈øerable condition of all other a≈ø≈øociations, who have indeed a fellow≈øhip, but mo≈øt abominable and ba≈øe, with the fruitle≈ø≈øe works of darkne≈ø≈øe, Ephe≈ø. 5. 11. As al≈øo mo≈øt dangerous, and dreadfull, Prov. 13. 20. Acompanion of fooles ≈øhalbe de≈øtroyed.

Thirdly, I hope al≈øo that you of the wi≈øer ≈øort of tho≈øe who as yet are without having any well-wi≈øhes unto your ≈øelves, are per≈øwaded to flee amaine, ≈øeeking an ha≈øty e≈øcape from all tho≈øe unfruitfull fellow≈øhips with the deeds, and doers of darkne≈ø≈øe; as Lot from Sodome ≈øo full of villany, ≈øo neare de≈øtruction; and to ha≈øten ≈øpeedily, as the creatures into Noahs Arke, to be firmely knit, and in≈øeparably incorporated into this ≈øociety, abounding with ≈øuch felicities, and contentments.

4. And I doubt not but that you which have already admittance into, and acquaintance in this goodfellow≈øhippe, by the former particulars are animated, and encouraged to cleave more clo≈øely unto, and to proceed more comfortably and couragiou≈øly in the ≈øame; it abounding with ≈øuch variety of excelling priviledges, and tran≈øcendent prerogatives,
maugre Sathans ≈øubtill and helli≈øh temptations, and the worlds de≈øpightfull u≈øage, and injurious calumniations.

Of which hopes if I doe not faile, I have that I labour for. I having declared the≈øe things unto you, 1. That you al≈øo (which as yet are ≈øtrangers from this heavenly communion) may have fellow≈øhippe with us, which you need not either dread or ≈øhame; for truly our fellow≈øhippe is with the Father, and his Sonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. 2. And that you which are infranchi≈øed into this Society, may walke forward comfortably and couragiou≈øly through the many cro≈ø≈øing oppo≈øitions you meet withall in he holy path. Or to end with the Apo≈øtles words, that your joy may be full.
